required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Mobile Health Intervention to Promote Positive Infant Health Outcomes in Guatemala
clinical_study.official_title: Mobile Health Intervention to Promote Positive Infant Health Outcomes in Guatemala

brief_summary.textblock: Promoting optimal development for children at risk in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) is an important global health priority. Supporting caregivers to provide nurturing care is an evidence-based strategy, however feasibility of scaling-up this supporting is limited by competing demands on health workers' time. For infant development, mHealth technologies have the potential to solve this problem by providing tailored content directly to caregivers, involving and empowering them to promote infant development, promoting and facilitating interactions with health workers when areas of concern are identified and, therefore, expanding the reach of healthcare systems. This study is designed to explore this idea, by designing a caregiver-directed smartphone application to directly engage first-time caregivers in rural Guatemala in providing nurturing care and, after design, to conduct a prospective implementation trial of its use followed by an adequately-powered efficacy study.

primary_outcome.description: Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development (3rd edition). Scores are norm-referenced based on age. Higher scores are better.

arm_group.arm_group_label: smartphone application to promote nurturing care
arm_group.description: a caregiver-directed smartphone application will directly engage first-time caregivers in providing nurturing care
caregivers will receive print materials on early childhood stimulation

intervention.intervention_name: smartphone application to promote nurturing care
intervention.arm_group_label: smartphone application to promote nurturing care

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- first-time caregivers with an infant in the eligible age range (0-4 weeks)
- infant from singleton birth
- infant from full-term (> 37 weeks gestation) birth
Exclusion Criteria:
- Presence of acute malnutrition/wasting or severe medical illness (heart disease, kidney disease, congenital abnormality) in the infant
- medical need for supplementation of breastfeeding
- caregiver not literate

overall_contact.last_name: Beth A Smith, PT, DPT, PhD

patient_data.ipd_description: de-identified data will be shared via NICHD DASH
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: data will become available upon completion of the study and will remain available indefinitely.
